div.p: THE Second part of Henrie the fourth, continuing to his death, and coronation of Henrie the fift.
With the humours of sir Iohn Falstaffe, and swaggering Pistoll.
As it hath been sundrie times publikely acted by the right honourable, the Lord Chamberlaine his seruants.
LONDON Printed by V. S. for Andrew Wise, and William Aspley. 1600.

div.head: The second part of Henry the fourth, continuing to his death, and coronation of Henry the fift.
div.stage: Enter Rumour painted full of Tongues.
div.l: OPen your eares; for which of you wi'l stop
The vent of hearing, when lowd Rumor speaks?
I from the Orient to the drooping West,
(Making the wind my poste-horse) still vnfold
The acts commenced on this ball of earth,
Vpon my tongues continuall slanders ride,
The which in euery language I pronounce,
Stuffing the eares of men with false reports,
I speake of peace while couert enmity,
Vnder the smile of safety, woundes the world:
And who but Rumor, who but onely I,
Make fearefull musters, and prepar'd defence,
Whiles the bigge yeare, swolne with some other griefe,
Is thought with child by the sterne tyrant Warre?
And no such matter Rumour is a pipe,
Blowne by surmizes, Ieolousies coniectures,
And of so easie, and so plaine a stop,
That the blunt monster, with vncounted heads,
The still discordant wau'ring multitude,
Can play vpon it. But what need I thus
(My wel knowne body) to anothomize
Among my houshold? why is Rumor here?
I runne before King Harries victorie,
Who in a bloudy field by Shrewsbury,
Hath beaten downe yong Hot-spurre and his troopes▪
Quenching the flame of bold rebellion,
Euen with the rebels bloud. Put what meane I
To speake so true at first▪ my office is
To noyse abroad, that Harry Monmouth fell
Vnder the wrath of noble Hot-spurs sword,
And that the King before the Douglas rage,
Stoope his annointed head as low as death.
This haue I rumour'd through the peasant townes,
Betweene that royall field of Shrewsbury,
And this worme-eaten hole of ragged stone,
When Hot-spurs father old Northumberland
Lies crafty sicke, the postes come trying on,
And not a man of them brings other newes,
Than they haue learnt of me, from Rumors tongues,
They bring smooth comforts false, worse then true wrongs.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Bardolfe at one doore.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Who keepes the gate here ho? where is the Earle?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: What shall I say you are?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Tell thou the Earle,
That the Lord Bardolfe doth attend him heere.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: His Lordship is walkt forth into the orchard,
Please it your honor knocke but at the gate,
And he himselfe will answer. Enter the Earle Northumberland▪

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Here comes the Earle.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: What newes Lord Bardolfe? euery minute now
Should be the father of some Stratagem,
The times are wild, contention like a horse,
Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loofe,
And beares downe all before him.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Noble Earle,
I bring you certaine newes from Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Good, and God will.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: As good as heart can wish:
The King is almost wounded to the death,
And in the fortune of my Lord your sonne,
Prince Harry slaine outright, and both the Blunts
Kild by the hand of Dowglas, yong prince Iohn,
And Westmerland and Stafford fled the field,
And Harry Monmouthes brawne the hulke sir Iohn,
Is prisoner to your sonne: O such a day!
So fought, so followed, and so fairely wonne,
Came not till now to dignifie the times
Since Caesars fortunes.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: How is this deriu'd?
Saw you the field? came you from Shrewsbury?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I spake with one, my lord, that came from thence, enter Trauers.
A gentleman well bred, and of good name,
That freely rendred me these newes for true.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Here comes my seruant Trauers who I sent
On tuesday last to listen after newes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My lord, I ouer-rode him on the way,
And he is furnisht with no certainties,
More then he haply may retale from me.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Now Trauers, what good tidings comes with you●

sp.speaker: Trauers
sp.l: My lord, sir Iohn Vmfreuile turnd me backe
With ioyfull tidings▪ and being better horst,
Out rode me, after him came spurring hard,
A gentleman almost forespent with speede,
That stopt by me to breathe his bloudied horse,
He askt the way to Chester, and of him
I did demand what newes from Shrewsbury,
He told me that rebellion had bad lucke,
And that yong Harrie Percies spur was cold:
With that he gaue his able horse the head,
And bending forward, strooke his armed heeles,
Against the panting sides of his poore iade,
Vp to the rowell head, and starting so,
He seem'd in running to deuoure the way,
Staying no longer question.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Ha● againe,
Said he, yong Harry Percies spur was cold,
Of Hot-spurre, Cold-spurre, that rebellion
Had met ill lucke?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: My lord, Ile tell you what,
If my yong Lord your sonne, haue not the day,
Vpon mine honor for a silken point,
Ile giue my Barony, neuer talke of it.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Why should that gentleman that rode by Trauers,
Giue then such instances of losse?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Who he?
He was some hilding fellow that had stolne
The horse he rode on, and vpon my life
Spoke at a venter. Looke, here comes more news. enter Morton.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Yea this mans brow, like to a title leafe,
Foretells the nature of a tragicke volume,
So lookes the strond, whereon the imperious floud,
Hath left a witnest vsurpation.
Say Mourton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury?

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: I ranne from Shrewsbury my noble lord,
Where hatefull death put on his vgliest maske,
To fright our partie.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: How doth my sonne and brother?
Thou tremblest, and the whitenes in thy cheeke,
Is apter then thy tongue to tell thy arrand,
Euen such a man, so faint, so spirritlesse,
So dull, so dead in looke, so woe begon,
Drew Priams curtaine in the dead of night,
And would haue told him, halfe his Troy was burnt:
But Priam found the fier, ere he, his tongue,
And I, my Percies death ere thou reportst it.
This thou wouldst say, Your son did thus and thus,
Your brother thus: so fought the noble Dowglas,
Stopping my greedy eare with their bold deedes,
But in the end, t● stop my eare indeed,
Thou hast a sigh to blow away this praise,
Ending with brother, sonne, and all are dead.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: Douglas is liuing, and your brother yet,
But for my Lord your sonne:

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Why he is dead?
See what a ready tongue Suspition hath!
He that but feares the thing hee would not know,
Hath by instinct, knowledge from others eies,
That what he feard is chanced: yet speake Mourton,
Tell thou an Earle, his diuination lies,
And I will take it as a sweete disgrace,
And make thee rich for doing me such wrong.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: You are too great to be by me gainsaid,
Your spirite is too true, your feares too certaine.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Yet for all this, say not that Percie's dead,
I see a strange confession in thine eie,
Thou shakst thy head, and holdst it feare or sinne,
To speake a truth: if he be slaine,
The tongne offends not that reports his death,
And he doth sinne that doth belie the dead,
Not he which saies the dead is not aliue,
Yet the first bringer of vnwelcome newes
Hath but a loosing office, and his tongue
Sounds euer after as a ●ullen bell,
Remembred tolling a departing friend.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: I cannot thinke, my Lord, your sonne is dead▪

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: I am sory I should force you to beleeue,
That which I would to God I had not seene,
But these mine eies saw him in bloudy state,
Rendring faint quittance, wearied, and out-breathd,
To Harry Monmouth, whose swift wrath beat downe
The neuer daunted Percy to the earth,
From whence with life he neuer more sprung vp.
In few his death, whose spirite lent a fire,
Euen to the dullest peasant in his campe,
Being bruted once, tooke fire and heate away,
From the best temperd courage in his troopes,
For from his mett●l was his party steeled,
Which once in him abated, o● the rest
Turnd on themselues, like dull and heauy lead.
And as the thing thats heauy in it selfe,
Vpon enforcement flies with greatest speed:
So did our men, heauy in Hot-spurs losse,
Lend to this weight such lightnosse with their feare,
That arrowes fled not swifter toward their ayme,
Than did our souldiers aiming at their safetie,
Fly from the field: then was that noble Worcester,
So soone tane prisoner, and that furious Scot,
The bloudy Douglas whose well labouring sword▪
Had three times slaine th'appearance of the King,
Can vaile his stomacke and did grace the shame
Of those that turnd their backes, and in his flight,
Stumbling in feare, was tooke: the summe of all
Is, that the King hath wonne, and hath sent out,
A speedy power to incounter you my lord,
Vnder the conduct of yong Lancaster,
And Westmerland: this is the news at ful.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: For this I shal haue time enough to mourne▪
In poison there is phisicke, and these newes,
Hauing beene wel, that would haue made me sicke:
Being sicke, haue (in some measure) made me wel:
And as the wretch whose feuer-weakned ioynts,
Like strengthlesse hinges buckle ●●der life,
Impacient of his fit, breakes like a fire
Out of his keepers armes; euen so my limbes,
Weakened with griefe being ●ow enragde with griefe,
Are thrice themselues: hence therfore thou nice crutch,
A scaly gauntlet now with ioynts of steele
Must gloue this hand and hence thou sickly co●●e,
Thou art a guard too wanton for the head,
Which princes, flesh● with conquest, ayme to hit:
Now bind my browes 〈◊〉 yron, and approach
The raggedst houre 〈…〉 and Spight dare bring,
To frowne vpon th' 〈◊〉 Northumberland,
Let heauen kisse earth, now let not Natures hand
Keepe the wild floud con●ind, let Order die,
And let this world no longer be a stage,
To feed contention in a lingring act:
But let one spirite of the first borne Cain
Raigne in all bosomes, that ech heart being set
On bloudy courses, the rude sceane may end,
And darknesse be the burier of the dead.

sp.speaker: Vmfr.
sp.l: This strained passion doth you wrong my lord.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Sweet earle, diuorce not wisedom from your honor,

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: The liues of all your louing complices,
Leaue on you health, the which if you giue ore,
To stormy passion must perforce decay.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: We all that are ingaged to this losse,
Knew that we ventured on such dangerous seas,
That if we wrought out life, twas ten to one,
And yet we venturd for the gaine proposde,
Choakt the respect of likely perill fear'd,
And since we are oreset, venture againe:
Come, we will al put forth body and goods.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: Tis more then time, and my most noble lord,
I heare for certaine, and dare speake the truth.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: I knew of this before, but to speake truth,
This present griefe had wipte it from my mind,
Go in with me and counsell euery man,
The aptest way for safety and reuenge,
Get postes and letters, and make friends with speed,
Neuer so few, and neuer yet more need. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Iohn alone, with his page bearing his sword and buckler.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sirra, you giant, what saies the doctor to my water?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: He said sir, the water it self was a good healthy water, but for the party that owed it, he might haue moe diseases then he knew for.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Men of al sorts take a pride to gird at me: the braine of this foolish compounded clay-man is not able to inuent any thing that intends to laughter, more then I inuent, or is inuented on me, I am not only witty in my selfe, but the cause that wit is in other men. I do here walk before thee, like a sow that hath ouerwhelmd al her litter but one, if the prince put thee into my seruice for any other reason then to sett me off, why then I haue no iudgement thou horeson mandrake, thou art sitter to be worne in my cap, then to wait at my heels I was neuer manned with an agot till now, but I wil in-set you, neither in golde nor siluer, but in vile apparell, and send you backe againe to your master for a iewell, the ●●uenall the prince your master, whose chin is not yet fledge, I will sooner haue a beard grow in the palme of my hand, then he shal get one off his cheek, & yet he will not sticke to say his face is a face royal, God may finish it when he will, tis not a haire amisse yet, he may keepe it still at a face royall, for a barber shall neuer earne sixpence out of it, and yet heele be crowing as if he had writte man euer since his father was a batcheler, he may keepe his owne grace, but hees almost out of mine I can assure him: what said master Dommelton about the sattin for my short cloake and my sloppes?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He saide sir, you should procure him better assurance then Bardolfe, he would not take his band and yours, he liked not the securitie.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
Let him be damn'd like the glutton, pray God his tongue be hotter, a horeson A chitophella rascall: yea forsooth knaue, to beare a gentle man in hand, and then stand vpon security, the horson smoothy-pates doe now weare nothing but hie shooes and bunches of keyes at their girdles, and if a man is through with them in honest taking vp, then they must stand vppon security, I had as liue they would put ratsbane in my mouth as offer to stop it with security, I lookt a should haue sent me two and twenty yards of sattin (as I am a true knight,) and he sends me security: well he may sleepe in security, for he hath the horne of abundance, and the lightnesse of his wife
shines through it: wheres Bardolf, & yet can not he see though he haue his owne lanthorne to light him.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Hees gone in Smithfield to buy your worship a horse.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I bought him in Paules, and heele buy me a horse in Smithfield, and I could get me but a wife in the stewes, I were man●d, horsde, and wiu●d.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Sir, here comes the noble man that committed the prince for striking him about Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wait close, I will not see him.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.p: Whats hee that goes there?

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Falstaffe and't please your lordship.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: He that was in question for the rob'ry?

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: He my Lord, but he hath since done good seruice at Shrewsbury, & (as! heare,) is now going with some charge to the lord Iohn of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What to Yorke? call him backe againe.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Boy, tell him I am deafe.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: You must speake lowder, my master is deafe.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I am sure he is to the hearing of any thing good, goe plucke him by the elbow, I must speake with him.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What? a yong knaue and begging? is there not wars? is there not employment? doth not the King lacke subiects? do not the rebels need souldiers, though it be a shame to be on any side but one, it is worse shame to beg then to be on the worst side, were it worse then the name of Rebellion can tell how to make it.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: You mistake me sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Why sir, did I say you were an honest man, setting my knighthood and my souldiership aside, I had lied in my throat if I had said so.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: I pray you sir then set your knighthood, and your soldiership aside, and giue me leaue to tell you, you lie in your throate, if you say I am any other then an honest man.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: I giue thee leaue to tell me, so I lay aside that which growes to me, if thou getst any leaue of me, hang me, if thou takst leaue, thou wert better be hangd, you hunt counter, hence, auaunt.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My good Lord, God giue your lordship good time of day, I am glad to see your lordship abroade, I heard say your lordship was sicke, I hope your lordship goes abroade by aduise, your lordship, though not clean past your youth, haue yet some smack of an aguein you, some relish of the saltnes of time in you, and I most humbly beseech your lordship to haue a reuerend care of your health.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.p: Sir Iohn, I sent for you before your expedition to Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Andt please your lorship, I heare his maiesty is returnd with some discomfort from Wales.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I talke not of his maiesty, you would not come when I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And I heare moreouer, his highnes is falne into this same horson a poplexi.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well, God mend him, I pray you let me speake with you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: This appoplexi as I take it? is a kind of lethergie, and't please your lordship, a kind of sleeping in the bloud, a horson tingling.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What tell you me of it, be it as it is.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: It hath it originall from much griefe from study▪ and perturbation of the braine, I haue read the cause of his effects in Galen, it is a kind of deafenes.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I think you are falne into the disease, for you heare not what I say to you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Very wel my lord, very wel, rather and't please you it is the disease of not listning the maladie of not marking that I am troubled withall.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
To punish you by the heeles, would amend the attention
of your eares, and I care not if I doe become your phisitian.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I am as poore as Iob my lord, but not so pacient, your Lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me, in respect of pouerty, but how I should be your pacient to follow your prescriptions, the wise may make som dramme of a scruple or indeede a scruple it selfe.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I sent for you when there were matters against you for your life to come speake with me.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: As I was then aduisde by my learned counsail in the lawes of this land seruice, I did not come.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Wel, the truth is sir Iohn, you liue in great infamy.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: He that buckles himselfe in my belt cannot liue in lesse.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Your meanes are very slender, and your waste is great.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I would it were otherwise, I would my meanes were greater and my waste slender.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You haue misled the youthfull prince.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: The yong prince hath misled me, I am the felow with the great belly, and he my dogge.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Wel, I am loth to gall a new heald wound, your daies seruice at Shrewsbury, hath a little guilded ouer your nights exploit on Gadshill, you may thanke th●vnquiet time, for your quiet oreposting that action.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: But since all is well, keepe it so, wake not a sleeping wolfe.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: To wake a wolfe, is as bad as smell a fox.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What you are as a candle, the better part, burnt out.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: A wassel candle my lord, al tallow, if I did say of wax, my growth would approue the truth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: There is not a white haire in your face, but should haue his effect of grauity.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: His effect of grauy, grauie, grauie.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You follow the yong prince vp and downe, like his ill angell.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Not so my lord, your ill angell is light, but I hope he that lookes vpon me will take me without weighing, and yet in some respects I grant I cannot go. I cannot tell, vertue is of so little regard in these costar-mongers times, that true valour is turnd ●erod, Pregnancie is made a Tapster, & his quick wit wasted in giuing reckonings, all the other giftes appertinent to man, as the malice of his age shapes the one not worth a goosbery, you that are old consider not the capacities of vs that are yong, you doe measure the heate of our liuers with the bitternesse of your galles, and we that are in the vaward of our youth, I must confesse are wagges too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Do you set downe your name in the scroule of youth, that are written downe▪ old with all the characters of age? haue you not a moist eie, a dry hand, a yelow cheeke, a white beard, a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? is not your voice broken, your winde short, your chinne double, your wit single, and euery part about you blasted with antiquitie, and will you yet call your selfe yong? fie, fie, fie, sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: My Lorde, I was borne about three of the clocke in the afternoone, with a white head, and something a round bellie, for my voyce, I haue lost it with hallowing, and singing of Anthems: to approoue my youth further, I will not: the truth is, I am onely olde in iudgement and vnderstanding: and hee that wil caper with me for a thousand markes, let him lend me the money, and haue at him for the boxe of the ●e●re that the Prince gaue you, he gaue it like a rude Prince, and you tooke it like a sensible Lord: I haue checkt him for it, and the yong lion repents, mary not in ashes and sackcloth, but in new silke, and olde sacke.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Well, God send the prince a better companion.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: God send the companion a better prince, I cannot ridde my hands of him.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Well, the King hath seuerd you: I heare you are going with lord Iohn of Lancaster against the Archbishop and the Earle of Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Yea, I thanke your prety sweet witte for it: but looke
you pray, all you that kisse my lady Peace at home, that our armies ioyne not in a hote day, for, by the Lord, I take but two shirts out with me, and I meane not to sweate extraordinarily: if it be a hot day, & I brandish any thing but a bottle. I would I might neuer spit white again: there is not a dangerous action can peepe out his head▪ but I am thrust vpon it. Wel, I cannot last euer, but it was alway yet the tricke of our English nation, if they haue a good thing, to make it too common. If yee will needs say I am an olde man you should giue me rest: I would to God my name were not so terrible to the enemy as it is, I were better to be eaten do death with a rust, than to be scoured to nothing with perpetuall motion.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Well, be honest▪ be honest, and God blesse your expedition.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Will your lordship lend me a thousand pound to furnish me forth?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Not a penny, not a penny, you are too impatient to beare crosses: fare you well: commend mee to my coosine Westmerland.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: If I do, fillip me with a three man beetle: A man can no more separate age and couetousnesse, than a can part yong limbs and lechery, but the gowt galles the one, and the pox pinches the other, and so both the degrees preuent my curses, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: What money is in my purse?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Seuen groates and two pence.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I can get no remedy against this consumption of the purse, borrowing onely lingers and lingers it out, but the disease is incurable: Go beare this letter to my lord of Lancaster, this to the Prince, this to the Earle of Westmerland, and this to olde mistris Vrsula, whome I haue weekely sworne to marry since I perceiud the first white haire of my chin: about it, you know where to finde me: a pox of this gowt, or a gowt of this pox, for the one or the other playes the rogue with my great toe. Tis no matter if I doe hault, I haue the warres for my color, and my pension shal seeme the more reasonable: a good
wit will make vse of any thing; I will turne diseases to commoditie. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter th' Archbishop, Thomas Mowbray (Earle Marshall) the Lord Hastings, Fauconbridge, and Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Thus haue you heard our cause, and knowne our meanes,
And my most noble friends, I pray you al
Speake plainely your opinions of our hopes,
And first Lord Marshall, what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Marsh.
sp.l: I well allow the occasion of our armes,
But gladly would be better satisfied,
How in our meanes we should aduance ourselues,
To looke with forehead, bold, and big enough,
Vpon the power and puissance of the King.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Our 〈…〉 musters grow vpon the file,
To fiue and twenty thousand men of choise,
And our supplies liue largely in the hope
Of great Northumberland, whose bosome burnes
With an incensed fire of iniuries.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: The question then Lord Hastings standeth thus,
Whether our present fiue and twentie thousand,
May hold vp head without Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With him we may.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Yea mary, theres the point,
But if without him we be thought too feeble,
My iudgement is we should not step too far.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Tis very true lord Bardolfe, for indeede
It was yong Hot-spurs cause at Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: It was my Lord, who lined himselfe with hope,
Eating the ayre, and promise of supplie,
Flattring himselfe in proiect of a power,
Much smaller then the smallest of his thoughts,
And so with great imagination,
Proper to mad-men, led his powers to death,
And winking, leapt into destruction.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: But by your leaue it neuer yet did hurt,
To lay downe likelihoods and formes of hope.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: We fortifie in paper and in figures,
Vsing the names of men in steed of men,
Like on that drawes the model of an house,
Beyond his power to build it, who (halfe thorough)
Giues ore, and leaues his part-created cost,
A naked subiect to the weeping clowdes,
And waste for churlish winters tyrannie.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Grant that our hopes (yet likely of faire birth)
Should be stil borne, and that we now possest
The vtmost man of expectation,
I thinke we are so, body strong enough,
Euen as we are to equal with the King.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: What, is the King but ●iue and twenty thousand?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: To vs no more, nay not so much 〈◊〉 Bardolfe,
For his diuisions, as the times do brawle,
And in three heads, one power against the French,
And one against Glendower perforce a third
Must take vp vs, so is the vnfirme King
In three diuided, and his coffers sound
With hollow pouertie and emptinesse.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: That he should draw his seuerall strengths togither,
And come against vs in full puissance,
Need not to be dreaded.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: If he should do so, French and Welch he leaues his back vnarmde, they baying him at the heeles, neuer feare that.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who is it like should leade his forces hither?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: The Duke of Lancaster and Westmerland:
Against the Welsh, himself and Harry Monmouth:
But who is substituted against the French
I haue no certaine notice.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Shall we go draw our numbers, and set on?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: We are Times subiects, and Time bids be gone. ex.

div.stage: Enter Hostesse of the Tauerne, and an Officer or two.

sp.speaker: Hostesse
sp.p: Master Phang, haue you entred the action?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: It is entred.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wheres your yeoman? ist a lusty yeoman? wil a stand too't?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: Sirra, wheres Snare?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O Lord I, good master Snare.

sp.speaker: Snare
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: Snare, we must arest sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yea good master Snare, I haue entred him and all.

sp.speaker: Snare
sp.p: It may chaunce cost some of vs our liues, for he will stabbe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Alas the day, take heed of him, he stabd me in mine owne house, most beastly in good faith, a cares not what mischiefe he does, if his weapon be out, he will foyne like any diuell, he will spare neither man, woman, nor child.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: If I can close with him, I care not for his thrust.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No nor I neither, le be at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: And I but fist him once, and a come but within my view.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I am vndone by his going, I warrant you, hees an infinitiue thing vppon my score, good maister Phang holde him sure, good master Snare let him not scape, a comes continually to Pie corner (sauing your manhoods) to buy a saddle, and he is indited to dinner to the Lubbers head in Lumbert streete to master Smooths the silk man, I pray you since my exion is entred, and my case so openly knowne to the worlde, let him be brought in to his answer, a hundred marke is a long one, for a poore lone woman to beare and I haue borne, and borne, and borne, and haue bin fubd off, and fubd off, and fubd off from this day to that day, that it is a shame to be thought on, there is no honesty in such dealing, vnlesse a woman should be made an asse, and a beast, to beare euery knaues wrong: yonder he comes, and that arrant malmsie-nose knaue Bardolfe with him, do your offices do your offices master Phang, & master Snare, do me, do me, do me your offices.

div.stage: Enter sir Iohn, and Bardolfe, and the boy.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: How now, whose mare's dead? whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: I arrest you at the sute of mistris, quickly.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Away varlets, draw Bardolfe, cut me off the villaines head, throw the queane in the channell.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Throw me in the channell? Ile throw thee in the channel, wilt thou, wilt thou, thou bastardly rogue, murder murder, a thou honisuckle villaine, wilt thou kill Gods officers and the Kings? a thou honiseed rogue, thou art a honiseed, a man queller, and a woman queller.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Keepe them off Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: A reskew, a reskew.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Good people bring a reskew or two, thou wot, wot thou, thou wot, wot ta, do do thou rogue, do thou hempseed.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Away you scullian, you rampallian, you fustilarian, ile tickle your catastrophe.

div.stage: Enter Lord chiefe iustice and his men.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: What is the matter? keepe the peace here, ho.

sp.speaker: Hostesse
sp.p: Good my lord be good to me, I beseech you stand to me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How now sir Iohn, what are you brawling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and businesse?
You should haue bin well on your way to Yorke:
Stand from him fellow wherefore hang'st thou vpon him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O my most worshipful Lord, and't please your grace I am a poore widdow of Eastcheape, and he is arrested at my sute.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: For what summe?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: It is more then for some my Lord, it is for al I haue, he hath eaten me out of house and home, he hath put all my substance into that fat belly of his, but I will haue some of it out againe, or I wil ride thee a nights like the mare.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I think I am as like to ride the mare if I haue any vantage of ground to get vp.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p:
How comes this sir Iohn? what man of good temper would endure this tempest of exclamation, are you not ashamed to inforce a poore widdow, to so rough a course to come
by her owne.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What is the grosse summe that I owe thee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Mary if thou wert an honest man, thy selfe and the mony too: thou didst sweare to me vpon a parcell guilt goblet, sitting in my dolphin chamber, at the round table by a sea cole fire, vpon wednesday in Wheeson weeke, when the prince broke thy head, for liking his father to a singing man of Winsor, thou didst sweare to me them, as I was washing thy wound, to marry me, and make me my lady thy wife, canst thou deny 〈◊〉 did not goodwife Keech the butchers wife come in then and cal me gossip Quickly, comming in to borow a messe of vinegar, telling vs she had a good dish of prawnes, whereby thou didst desire to eate some, whereby I told thee they were ill for a greene wound, and didst thou not, when she was gone down stayers, desire me, to be no more so familiarity, with such poore people, saying that ere long they should cal me madam, and didst thou not kisse me, and bid me fetch thee thirtie shillings, I put thee now to thy booke oath, dome it if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My lord this is a poore made●oule, and she saies vp and downe the towne, that her eldest sonne is like you, she hath bin in good case and the trueth is pouerty hath distracted her, but for these foolish officers, I beseech you I may haue redresse against them.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Sir Iohn sir Iohn, I am wel acquainted with your maner of wrenching the true cause, the false way: it is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such more then impudent sawcines from you can thrust me from a leuel con●ideration: you haue as it appeares to me practisde vpon the easie yeelding spirite of this woman, and made her serue your vses both in purse and in person.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yea in truth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Pray thee peace, pay her the debt you owe her, and vnpay the villany you haue done with her, the one you may doe with sterling mony, and the other with currant repentance.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
My Lord I will not vndergoe this snepe without reply, you cal honorable boldnes impudent sawcinesse, if a man
wil make curtsie and say nothing, he is vertuous, no my Lord my humble duty remembred, I will not bee your sutor, I say to you I do desire deliuerance from these officers, being vpon hasty imployment in the Kings affayres.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: You speake as hauing power to do wrong, but answer in th'effect of your reputation, and satisfie the poore woman.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Come hither hostesse.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Now master Gower, what newes. enter a messenger.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: The King my Lord, and Harry prince of Wales,
Are neare at hand, the rest the paper tells.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Faith you said so before.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman, come, no more words of it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: By this heaunly ground I tread on, I must be faine to pawne both my plate, & the tapestry of my dining chambers-

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Glasses glasses is the onely drinking, and for thy wals a pretty sleight drollery, or the storie of the prodigal, or the Iarman hunting in waterworke, is worth a thousand of these bed-hangers, and these flie bitten tapestrie, let it be x. ● if thou canst: come, and twere not for thy humors, theres not a better wench in England, goe wash thy face and draw the action, come thou must not be in this humor with me, dost not know me, come, come, I know thou wast set on to this.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Pray thee sir Iohn let it be but twentie nobles, ifaith I am loath to pawne my p●●te so God saue me law.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Let it alone, ile make other shift, youle be a foole stil.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Well, you shall haue it, though I pawne my gowne, I hope youle come to supper, youle pay me altogether.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Wil I liue? goe with her, with her, hooke on, hooke on. exit hostesse and sergeant.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Will you haue Doll Tere-sheet meete you at supper.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No more words, lets haue her.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: I haue heard better newes.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Whats the newes my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Where lay the King to night?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: At Billingsgate my Lord.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I hope my Lord als wel, what is the newes my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Come all his forces backe?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: No, fifteen hundred foot, fiue hundred horse
Are marcht vp to my lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland, and the Archbishop.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You shall haue letters of me presently,
Come, go along with me, good master Gower.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Falstaffe
sp.p: Maister Gower, shall I intreate you with mee to dinner?

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.p: I must waite vpon my good lord here, I thank you good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Sir Iohn, you loyter heere too long,
Being you are to take souldiers vp
In Counties as you go.

sp.speaker: Falstaffe
sp.l: Will you suppe with mee maister Gower?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: What foolish maister taught you these manners, sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Falstaffe
sp.p: Maister Gower, if they become me not, hee was a foole that taught them mee: this is the right fencing grace, my Lord, tap for tap, and so part faire.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Now the Lord lighten thee, thou art a great foole.

stage.hi: Enter the Prince, Poynes, sir s●●● Russel, with other.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Before God, I am exceeding weary.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Ist come to that? I had thought wearines durst not haue attacht one of so hie bloud.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Faith it does me, though it discolors the complexion of my greatnes to acknowledge it: doth it not shew vildly in me to desire small beere?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Why a Prince should not be so loosely studied, as to remember so weake a composition.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Belike then my appetite was not princely gote, for by my troth, I do now remember the poor creature smal beere.
But indeed these humble considerations make me out of loue with my greatnesse. What a disgrace is it to mee to remember thy name? or to know thy face to morow? or to take note how many paire of silke stockings thou hast with these, and those that were thy peach colourd once, or to beare the inuentorie of thy shirts, as one for superfluitie, and another for vse. But that the Tennis court keeper knows better than I, for it is a low eb of linnen with thee when thou keepest not racket there, as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of the low Countries haue eate vp thy holland: and God knows whether those that bal out the ruines of thy linnen shal inherite his kingdom: but the Midwines say, the children are not in the fault wherevpon the world increases, and kinreds are mightily strengthened.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: How ill it followes, after you haue labored so hard, you should talke so ydlely! tell me how many good yong princes woulde doe so, their fathers being so sicke, as yours at this time is.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Shall I tel thee one thing Poynes?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Yes faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: It shall serue among wittes of no higher breeding then thine.

sp.speaker: Poynes.
sp.p: Go to, I stand the push of your one thing that you will tell.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Mary I tell thee it is not meete that I should bee sad now my father is sicke, albeit I could tell to thee, as to one it pleases me for fault of a better to call my friend, I could be sad, and sad indeede too.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Very hardly, vpon such a subiect.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: By this hand, thou thinkest me as farre in the diuels booke, as thou and Falstaffe, for obduracie and persistancie, let the end trie the man, but I tel thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my father is so sick, and keeping such vile company as thou arte, hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrowe.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: The reason.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What wouldst thou thinke of me if I should weep?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: I woulde thincke thee a most princely hyprocrite.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: It would bee euery mans thought, and thou arte a blessed felow, to thinke as euery man thinkes, neuer a mans thought in the world, keepes the rode way better then thine, euerie man would thinke me an hypocrite indeede, and what accites your most worshipfull thought to thinke so?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Why because you haue been so lewd and so much engraffed to Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And to thee.

sp.speaker: Poyne
sp.p: By this light I am well spoke on, I can heare it with mine owne eares the worst that they can say of me is that I am a second brother, and that I am a proper fellow of my hands, and those two things I confesse I cannot helpe: by the masse here comes Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And the boy that I gaue Falstaffe, a had him from me Christian, and looke if the fat villaine haue not transformd him Ape.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: God saue your grace.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And yours most noble Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Come you vertuous asse, you bashfull foole, must you be blushing, wherefore blush you now? what a maidenly man at armes are you become? ist such a matter to get a pottle-pots maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: A calls me enow my Lord, through a red lattice, and I could discerne no part of his face from the window▪ at last I spied his eies, and me thought he had made two holes in the ale wiues pet●cote and so peept through.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Has not the boy profited?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Away you horson vpright rabble, away.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Away you rascally Altheas dreame, away.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Instruct vs boy, what dreame boy?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Mary my lord, Althear dreampt she was deliuered of a firebrand, and therefore I call him her dreame.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: A crownes worth of good interpretation there tis boy.

sp.speaker: Poines
sp.p: O that this blossome could be kept from cankers▪ well, there is sixpence to preserue thee.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: And you do not make him hangd among you, the gallowes shall haue wrong.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And how doth thy master Bardolfe?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Well my Lord, he heard of your graces comming to towne, theres a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Deliuerd with good respect, and how doth the martlemasse your master?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: In bodily health sir.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Mary the immortall part needes a phisitian, but that moues not him, though that be sicke, it dies not.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: I do allow this Wen to be as familiar with me, as my dogge and he holds his place, for looke you how he writes.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Iohn Falstaffe Knight, euery man must know that as oft as he has occasion to name himselfe: euen like those that are kin to the King for they neuer pricke their finger, but they saye, theres some of the Kings bloud spilt: how comes that (saies he) that takes vppon him not to conceiue the answer is as ready as a borowed cap: I am the Kings poore cosin, sir.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Nay they will be kin to vs, or they will fetch it from Iaphet, but the letter, Sir Iohn Falstaffe knight, to the sonne of the king, nearest his father, Harry prince of Wales, greeting.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Why this is a certificate.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Peace.
I will imitate the honourable Romanes in breuitie.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: He sure meanes breuity in breath, short winded, I commend mee to thee, I commend thee, and, I leaue thee, be not too familiar with Poynes, for he misuses thy fauours so much, that he sweares thou art to mary his sister Nel, repent at idle times as thou maist, and so farwel.
Thine by yea▪ and no, which is as much as to say, as thou vsest him, Iacke Falstaffe with my family, Iohn with my brothers and sisters, and sir Iohn with all Europe.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
My Lord, Ile steep this letter in sacke and make him
eate it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Thats to make him eate twenty of his words, but do you vse me, thus Ned? must I marrie your sister?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: God send the wench no worse fortune, but I never said so.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Wel, thus we play the fooles with the time, and the spirits of the wise sit in the clowdes and mocke vs, is your master here in London?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Yea my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Where sups he? doth the old boare feede in the old Franke?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheape.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What companie?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Sup any women with him?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: None my lord, but old mistris Quickly, and mistris Dol Tere-sheet.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What Pagan may that be?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: A proper gentlewoman sir, and a kinswoman of my masters.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Euen such kinne as the parish Hei●fors are to the towne ●ull, shall we steale vpon them Ned at supper?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: I am your shadow my Lord, ile follow you.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Sirra▪ you boy and Bardolfe, no worde to your master that I am yet come to towne; theres for your silence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I haue no tongue sir.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: And for mine sir, I will gouerne it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Fare you well: go, this Doll Tere-sheete should be some rode.

sp.speaker: Poyns
sp.p: I warrant you, as common as the way between S. Albons and London.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: How might we see Falstaffe bestow himself to night in his true colours, and not our selues be seene?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Put on two letherne ierkins and aprons, and waite vpon him at his table as drawers.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
From a god to a bul, a heauy descension, it was Ioues
case, from a pince to a prentise, a low transformation, that shal be mine, for in euery thing the purpose must weigh with the folly, follow me Ned. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Northumberland his wife, and the wife to Harry Percie.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: I pray thee louing wife and gentle daughter,
Giue euen way vnto my rough affaires,
Put not you on the visage of the times,
And be like them to Percy troublesome.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I haue giuen ouer, I will speake no more,
Do what you wil, your wisedome be your guide.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Alas sweete wife, my honor is at pawne,
And but my going, nothing can redeeme it.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: O yet for Gods sake go not to these wars,
The time was father, that you broke your word,
When you were more endeere to it then now,
When your owne Percie, when my hearts deere Harry,
Threw many a Northward looke, to see his father
Bring vp his powers, but he did long in vaine.
Who then perswaded you to stay at home?
There were two honors lost, yours▪ and your sonnes,
For yours, the God of heauen brighten it,
For his, it stucke vpon him as the sunne
In the grey vault of heauen, and by his light
Did all the Cheualry of England moue
To do braue acts, he was indeede the glasse
Wherein the noble youth did dresse themselues.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Beshrew your heart,
Faire daughter, you do draw my spirites from me,
With new lamenting ancient ouersights,
But I must go and meete with danger there,
Or it will seeke me in an other place,
And find me worse prouided.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O flie to Scotland,
Till that the nobles and the armed commons,
Haue of their puissance made a little taste.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: If they get ground and vantage of the King,
Then ioyne you with them like a ribbe of steele,
To make strength stronger: but for al our loues,
First let them trie themselues, so did your sonne,
He was so suffred, so came I a widow,
And neuer shall haue length of life enough,
To raine vpon remembrance with mine eies,
That it may grow and sprout as high as heauen,
For recordation to my noble husband.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Come, come▪ go in with me, tis with my mind,
As with the tide, sweld vp vnto his height,
That makes a stil stand, running neither way,
Faine would I go to meete the Archbishop,
But many thousand reasons hold me backe,
I will resolue for Scotland, there am I,
Till time and vantage craue my company. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p: What the diuel hast thou brought there apple Iohns? thou knowest sir Iohn cannot indure an apple Iohn.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: ●as thou saist true, the prince once set a dish of apple Iohns before him, and tolde him there were fiue more sir Iohns, and putting off his hat, said, I will now take my leaue of these six d●ie, round, old, withered Knights, it angred him to the heart, but he hath forgot that.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why then couer and set them downe, and see if thou canst find out Sneakes Noise, mistris Tere-sheet would faine heare some musique.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Dispatch, the roome where they supt is too hot, theile come in straight.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p: Sirra, here wil be the prince and master Poynes anon, and they will put on two of our ierkins and aprons, and sir Iohn must not know of it, Bardolfe hath brought word.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: By the mas here will be old vtis, it wil be an excellent stratagem.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p: Ile see if I can find out Sneake. exit

div.stage: Enter mistris Quickly, and Doll Tere-sheet.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.p: Yfaith sweet heart, me thinkes now you are in an excellent good temperalitie. Your pulsidge beates as extraordinarily as heart would desire, and your colour I warrant you is as red as any rose, in good truth law: but yfaith you haue drunke too much cannaries, and thats a maruelous searching wine, and it perfumes the bloud ere one can say, whats this, how do you now?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Better then I was: hem.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why thats well said, a good heart's worth gold: loe here comes sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: When Arthur first in court empty the iourdan and was a worthy King: how now mistris Doll?

sp.speaker: host.
sp.p: Sicke of a calme, yea good faith.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: So is all her sect, and they be once in a calme they are sicke.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: A pox damne you, you muddie rascall, is that all the comfort you giue me?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You make fat rascals mistris Dol.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: I make them? gluttonie, and diseases make, I make them not.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: If the cooke help to make the gluttonie you helpe to make the diseases Doll, we catch of you Doll, we catch of you graunt that my poore vertue, grant that.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Yea ioy, our chaines and our iewels.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Your brooches, pearles, & ouches for to serue brauely, is to come halting off, you know to come off the breach, with his pike bent brauely, and to surgerie brauely, to venture vpon the chargde chambers brauely.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Hang your selfe, you muddie Cunger, hang your selfe.

sp.speaker: host
sp.p: By my troth this is the old fashion, you two neuer meet but you fall to some discord, you are both ygood truth as rew matique as two dry tosts, you cannot one beare with anothers confirmities, what the goodyere one must beare▪ & that must ●e you, you are the weaker vessell, as they say▪ the emptier vessel.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Can a weake empty vessell beare such a huge full hogshead? theres a whole marchants venture of Burdeux stuffe in him, you haue not seene a hulke better stuft in the hold. Come, ile be friends with thee iacke, thou art going to the wars, and whether I shall euer see thee againe or no there is no body cares.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Sir, Antient pistols belowe, and would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Hang him swaggering rascal, let him not come hither it is the foule-mouthd'st rogue in England.

sp.speaker: host.
sp.p: If he swagger, let him not come here, no by my faith I must liue among my neighbours, ile no swaggerers, I am in good name, and same with the very best: shut the doore, there comes no swaggerers here, I haue not liu'd al this while to haue swaggering now, shut the doore I pray you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dost thou heare hostesse?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Pray ye pacifie your selfe sir Iohn, there comes no swaggerers here.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dost thou heare? it is mine Ancient.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Tilly fally, sir Iohn, nere tel me: & your ancient swaggrer comes not in my doores: I was before maister Tisicke the debuty tother day, & (as he said to me) twas no longer ago than wedsday last, I good faith neighbor Quickely, sayes he, maister Dumbe our minister was by then, neighbor Quickly (saies he) receiue those that are ciuil, for (saide he) you are in an ill name: now a saide so▪ I can tell whereupon. For (saies he) you are an honest woman, and well thought on, therefore take heede what ghests you receiue, receiue (saies he) no swaggering companions: there comes none here: you would blesse you to heare what he said: no, Ile no swaggrers.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Hees no swaggrer hostesse, a tame cheter ysaith, you may stroke him as gently as a puppy grey-hound, heele not swagger with a Barbary hen, if her feathers turne backe in any shew of resistance, call him vp Drawer.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Cheter call you him? I will barre no honest man my
house, nor no cheter, but I do not loue swagering by my troth, I am the worse when one saies swagger: feele maisters, how I shake, looke you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: T●resh.
sp.p: So you do hostesse.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Doe I? yea in very trueth doe I, and twere an aspen leafe, I cannot abide swaggrers.

stage.hi: Enter antient Pistol, and Bardolfes boy.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.p: God saue you sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Welcome ancient Pistoll, heere Pistoll, I charge you with a cuppe of sacke, do you discharge vpon mine hostesse.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I will discharge vpon her sir Iohn, with two bullets.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: she is pistoll proofe: sir, you shall not hardely offend her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Come, Ile drink no proofes, nor no bullets, Ile drink no more than will do me good, for no mans pleasure, I.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Then, to you mistris Dorothy, I will charge you.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Charge me? I scorne you, scuruy companion: what you poore base rascally cheting lacke-linnen mate? away you mouldie rogue, away, I am meate for your maister.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I know you mistris Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Away you cutpurse rascall, you filthy boung, away, by this wine Ile thrust my knife in your mouldie chappes and you play the sawcie cuttle with me. Away you bottle ale rascall, you basket hilt stale iuggler, you. Since when, I pray you sir: Gods light, with two points on your shoulder? much.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: God let me not liue, but I will murther your ruffe for this.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: No more Pistol, I would not haue you go off here, discharge your selfe of our company, Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No, good captaine Pistoll, not here, sweete captaine.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p:
Captain, thou abhominable damnd cheter, art thou not ashamed to be called Captaine? and Captaines were of my mind, they would trunchion you out, for taking their names vpon you, before you haue earnd them: you a captaine? you slaue, for what? for teareing a poore whoores ruffe in a bawdy house: hee a captaine! hang him rogue, he liues vpon mowldy
stewd pr●ins, and dried cakes: a captaine? Gods light these villaines wil make the word as odious as the word occupy, which was an excellent good worde before it was il sorted, therefore captains had neede look too●t.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Pray thee go downe good Ancient.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Hearke thee hither mistris Dol.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Not I, I tell thee what corporall Bardolfe, I could teare her, Ile be reuengde of her.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Pray thee go downe.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Ile see her damnd first, to Plutoes damnd lake by this hand to th'infernal deep, with erebus & tortures vile also: holde hooke and line, say I: downe, downe dogges, downe faters haue we not Hiren here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Good captaine Peesell be quiet, tis very late yfaith, I beseeke you now aggrauate your choller.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.p: These be good humors indeede, shal pack-horses, and hollow pamperd iades of Asia which cannot goe but thirtie mile a day, compare with Caesars and with Canibals, and troiant Greekes? nay rather damne them with King Cerbe●us, and let the Welkin roare, shall we fall foule for toies?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: By my troth captaine, these are very bitter words.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Be gone good Ancient, this will grow to a brawle anon.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Men like dogges giue crownes like pins, haue we not Hiren here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A my word Captaine, theres none such here, what the goodyeare do you thinke I would denie her? for Gods sake be quiet.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Then feed and be fat, my faire Calipolis, come giues some sacke, si fortune me tormente sperato me contento, feare we brode sides? no, let the fiend giue fire, giue me some sacke, and sweet hart, lie thou there, come we to ful points here? and are & caeteraes, no things?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Pistol, I would be quiet.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Sweet Knight, I kisse thy neaffe, what, we haue seene the seuen starres.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: For Gods sake thrust him down staires, I cannot indure such a fustian rascall.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.p: Thrust him downe staires, know we not Galloway nagges?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Quaite him downe Bardolfe like a shoue-groat shilling, nay, and a doe nothing but speake nothing, a shall be nothing here.

sp.speaker: Bard
sp.p: Come, get you downe staires.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: What shall we haue incision? shall we imbrew? then death rocke me a sleepe, abridge my dolefull daies: why then let grieuons gastly gaping wounds vntwinde the sisters three, come Atropose I say.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Heres goodly stuffe toward.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Giue me my rapier, boy.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: I pray thee Iacke, I pray thee do not drawe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Get you downe staires.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Heres a goodly tumult, ile forsweare keeping house afore ile be in these tirrits and frights, so, murder I warant now, alas, alas, put vp your naked weapons, put vp your naked weapons.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I pray thee Iack be quiet, the rascal's gone, ah you horson little vliaunt villaine you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Are you not hurte i'th groyne? me thought a made a shrewd thrust at your belly.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue you turnd him out a doores?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yea sir, the rascal's drunke, you haue hurt him sir i'th shoulder.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A rascall to braue me?

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: A you sweet little rogue you, alas poore ape how thou sweatst, come let me wipe thy face, come on you horsone chops: a rogue, yfaith I loue thee, thou art as valorous as Hector of Troy, woorth fiue of Agamemnon, & ten times better then the nine Worthies, a villaine!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ah rascally slaue! I will tosse the rogue in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Do and thou darst for thy heart, and thou dost, ile canuas thee betweene a payre of sheetes.

sp.speaker: Roy
sp.p: The musique is come sir. enter musicke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Let them play, play sirs, sit on my knee Doll, a rascall bragging slaue! the rogue fled from me like quicksiluer.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Yfaith and thou followdst him like a church, thou horson little tydee Bartholemew borepigge, when wilt thou leaue sighting a daies and foyning a nights, and begin to patch vp thine old body for heauen.

sp.speaker: Fal
sp.p: Peace good Doll, do not speake like a deathes head, do not bid me remember mine end.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Sirra, what humour's the prince of?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A good shallow yong fellow, a would haue made a good pantler, a would a chipt bread wel.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: They say Poines has a good wit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: He a good wit▪ hang him baboon, his wit's as thicke as Tewksbury mustard, theres no more conceit in him then is in a mallet.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Why does the prince loue him so then?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Because their legges are both of a bignesse▪ and a plaies at quoites well, and eates cunger and fennel, and drinkes off candles endes for slappe-dragons, and rides the wilde mare with the boyes, and iumpes vpon ioynd-stooles, and sweares with a good grace, and weares his bootes very smoothe like vnto the signe of the Legge, and breedes no bate with telling of discreet stories, and such other gambole faculties a has that show a weake minde, and an able bodie for the which the prince admits him: for the prince himself is such another, the weight of a haire wil turne scales between their haber de poiz.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Would not this naue of a wheele haue his eares cut off?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Lets beate him before his whore.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Looke where the witherd elder hath not his poule clawd like a parrot.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Is it not strange that desire should so many yeeres out liue performance.

sp.speaker: Falst▪
sp.p: Kisse me Doll,

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Saturne and Venus this yeere in coniunction? what saies th'Almanacke to that?

sp.speaker: Poyns
sp.p: And look whether the fierie Trigon his man be not lisping to his master, old tables, his note booke, his counsel keeper?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Thou dost giue me ●lattering busses.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: By my troth I kisse thee with a most constant heart.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I am old, I am old.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I loue thee better then I loue, ere a scuruy yong boy of them all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What stuffe wilt haue a kirtle of? I shall receiue mony a thursday, shalt haue a cap to morrow: a merry song come it growes late, weele to bed, thou●t forget me when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: By my troth thou't set me a weeping and thou saist so, proue that euer I dresse my selfe handsome til thy returne, wel hearken a▪ th end.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Some sacke Francis.

sp.speaker: Prince, Poynes
sp.p: Anon anon sir.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Ha? a bastard sonne of the Kings? and arte not thou Poynes his brother?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why thou globe of sinfull continents, what a life dost thou leade?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: A better then thou, I am a gentleman, thou art a drawer.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Very true sir, and I come to drawe you out by the eares.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O the Lord preserue thy grace: by my troth welcom to London, now the Lord blesse that sweete face of thine, O Iesu, are you come from Wales?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Thou horson madde compound of maiestie, by this light, flesh, and corrupt bloud, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: How? you fat foole I scorne you.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: My lorde, he will driue you out of your reuenge, and turne all to a meriment if you take not the heate.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You horson candlemine you, how vildly did you speake of me now, before this honest, vertuous, ciuill gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Gods blessing of your good heart, and so she is by my troth.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Didst thou heare me?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Yea and you knew me as you did, when you ranne away by Gadshil▪ you knew I was at your backe, and spoke it, on purpose to trie my patience.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No, no, no, not so, I did not thinke thou wast within hearing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: I shall driue you then to confesse the wilfull abuse, and then I know how to handle you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No abuse Hall a mine honour, no abuse.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Not to dispraise me, and cal me pantler and bread-chipper, and I know not what?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No abuse Hall.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: No abuse?

sp.speaker: Falst
sp.p: No abuse Ned i'th worlde, honest Ned, none, I dispraisde him before the wicked, that the wicked might not fall in loue with thee: in which doing, I haue done the part of a carefull friend and a true subiect, and thy father is to giue me thankes for it, no abuse Hall, none Ned, none, no faith boyes none.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: See now whether pure feare and intire cowardize, doth not make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with vs: is she of the wicked, is thine hostesse here of the wicked, or is thy boy of the wicked or honest Bardolfe whose zeal burnes in his nose of the wicked?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Answer thou dead elme, answer.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: The fiend hath prickt down Bardolfe irrecouerable, and his face is Lucifers priuy kitchin, where he doth nothing but rost mault-worms, for the boy there is a good angel about him, but the diuel blinds him too.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: For the weomen.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: For one of them shees in hell already, and burnes poore soules: for th'other I owe her mony, and whether she be damnd for that I know not.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No I thinke thou art not, I thinke thou art quit for that, mary there is another inditement vpon thee, for suffering flesh to be eaten in thy house contrary to the law, for the which I thinke thou wilt howle.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Al vitlars do so, whats a ioynt of mutton or twoo in a whole Lent?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: What saies your grace?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: His grace saies that which his flesh rebels against.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Who knockes so lowd at doore? looke too'th doore there Francis.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Peyto, how now, what newes?

sp.speaker: Peyto
sp.l: The King your father is at Westminster,
And there are twenty weake and wearied postes,
Come from the North, and as I came along
I met and ouertooke a dozen captaines,
Bareheaded, sweating, knocking at the Tauernes,
And asking euery one for sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: By heauen Poines, I feele me much too blame,
So idely to prophane the precious time,
When tempest of commotion like the south.
Borne with blacke vapour doth begin to melt,
And drop vpon our bare vnarmed heads,
Giue me my sword and cloke: Falstaffe good night.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now coms in the sweetest morsell of the night, & we must hence and leaue it vnpickt: more knocking at the doore, how now, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You must away to court sir presently,
A dozen captaines stay at doore for you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pay the musitions sirra, farewel hostesse, farewel Dol, you see my good wenches how men of merrite are sought after, the vndeseruer may sleepe, when the man of action is cald on, farewell good wenches, if I be not sent away poste, I will see you againe ere I goe.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I cannot speake, if my hart be not ready to burst: wel sweete Iacke, haue a care of thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wel, fare thee wel, I haue knowne thee these twentie nine yeeres, come pease-cod time, but an honester, and truer hearted man: wel, fare thee wel.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Mistris Tere-sheete.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Bid mistris Tere-sheete come to my maister.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O runne Doll, runne, runne good Doll, come, shee comes blubberd, yea? wil you come Doll? exeunt

div.stage: Enter Iustice Shallow, and Iustice Silens.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Come on, come on, come on, giue me your hand sir, giue me your hand sir, an early stirrer, by the Roode: and how doth my good coosin Silence?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Good morrow good coosine Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: And how doth my coosin your bedfellow? and your fairest daughter and mine, my god-daughter Ellen?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Alas, a blacke woosel, coosin Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: By yea, and no sir, I dare say my coosin William is become a good scholler, he is at Oxford stil, is he not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Indeede sir to my cost.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: A must then to the Innes a court shortly: I was once of Clements Inne, where I thinke they wil talke of mad Shallow yet.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: You were calld Lusty Shallow then, coosin.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: By the masse I was calld any thing, and I would haue done any thing indeede too, and roundly too: there was I, and little Iohn Doyt of Staffordshire, and blacke George Barnes, and Francis Pickebone, and Will Squele a Cotsole man, you had not foure such swinge bucklers in all the Innes a court againe, and I may say to you; wee knewe where the bona robes were, and had the best of them all at commaundement: then was Iacke Falstaffe, now sir Iohn, a boy, and page to Thomas Mowbray duke of Norffolke.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
This sir Iohn coosin, that comes hither anone about
souldiers?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: The same sir Iohn, the very same, I see him breake Skoggins head at the Court gate, when a was a Cracke, not thus high: and the very same day did I fight with one Samson Stockefish a Fruiterer behinde Greyes Inne: Iesu, Iesu, the mad dayes that I haue spent! and to see how many of my olde acquaintance are dead.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: We shal all follow, coosin.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Certaine, tis certaine, very sure, very sure, death (as the Psalmist saith) is certaine to all all shall die. How a good yoke of bullockes at Samforth faire?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: By my troth I was not there.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Death is certaine: Is old Dooble of your towne liuing yet?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Dead sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Iesu, Iesu, dead! a drew a good bow, and dead? a shot a fine shoote: Iohn a Gaunt loued him well, and betted much money on his head. Dead? a woulde haue clapt ith clowt at twelue score, and carried you a forehand shaft a fourteene and foureteene and a halfe, that it would haue doone a mans heart good to see. How a score of Ewes now?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thereafter as they bee, a score of good ewes may bee worth ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: And is olde Dooble dead?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Here come two of sir Iohn Falstaffes men, as I thinke.
sp.stage: Enter Bardolfe, and one with him
sp.l: Good morrow honest gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bardolfe
sp.l: I beseech you, which is iustice Shallow?

sp.speaker: Sha:
sp.p: I am Robart Shallowe, sir, a poore Esquier of this Countie, and one of the Kings iustices of the peace: what is your good pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Bard:
sp.p: My Captaine, sir, commends him to you, my Captain sir Iohn Falstaffe, a tall gentleman, by heauen, and a most gallant Leader.

sp.speaker: Sha:
sp.p:
He greetes me wel, sir, I knew him a good backsword man: how doth the good Knight? may I aske how my Ladie
his wife doth.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, pardon, a souldiour is better accommodate the● with a wife.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is well said infaith sir, and it is well said indeed too, better accomodated, it is good, yea indeede is it, good phrases are surely, and euer were, very commendable, accommodated, it comes of accommodo, very good, a good phrase.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Pardon sir, I haue heard the word, Phrase call you it? by this daye I knowe not the phrase, but I will maintaine the word with my sword to be a souldierlike word, and a word of exceeding good command by heauen, accommodated, that is when a man is as they say, accommodated, or when a man is being whereby, a may be thought to be accommodated, which is an excellent thing.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It is very iust, look, here comes good sir Iohn, giue me your good hand, giue me your worshippes good hand, by my troth you like well, and beare your yeeres very well, welcome good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I am glad to see you well, good master Robert Shallow, master Soccard (as I thinke.)

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: No sir Iohn, it is my cosen Scilens in commssion with me.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Good master Scilens, it well befits you should be of the peace.

sp.speaker: Scil.
sp.p: Your good worship is welcome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Fie this is hot weather gentlemen, haue you prouided me here halfe a dozen sufficient men?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Mary haue we sir, wil you sit?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Let me see them I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wheres the roule? wheres the roule? wheres the roule? let me see, let me see▪ let me see, so, so, so, so, so, (so, so) yea mary sir, Rafe Mouldy let them appeare as I cal, let them do, so, let them do, so, let me see, where is Mouldy?

sp.speaker: Mouldy
sp.p: Here, and 't please you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
What think you sir Iohn, a good limbde, felow, yong,
strong, and of good friends.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is thy name Mouldie?

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p: Yea, and 't please you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Tis the more time thou wert vsde.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, most excellent yfaith, things that are mouldy lacke vse: very singular good, infaith well said sir Iohn very well said. Iohn prickes him.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p: I was prickt wel enough before, and you could haue let me alone, my old dame will be vndone now for one to doe her husbandrie, and her drudgery, you need not to haue prickt me, there are other men fitter to go out then I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, peace Mouldy, you shall go, Mouldy it is time you were spent.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p: Spent?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Peace fellow, peace, stand aside, know you where you are? for th'other sir Iohn: let me see Simon Shadow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea mary, let me haue him to sit vnder, hees like to be a cold soldiour.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wheres Shadow?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Shadow, whose sonne art thou?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: My mothers sonne sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thy mothers sonnes like enough, and thy fathers shadow, so the sonne of the female is the shadow of the male: it is often so indeede, but much of the fathers substance.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Do you like him sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Shadow wil serue for summer, pricke him, for we haue a number of shadowes fill vp the muster booke.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Thomas Wart.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Wheres he?

sp.speaker: Wart
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is thy name Wart?

sp.speaker: Wart
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou art a very ragged wart.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Shall I pricke him sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
It were superfluous, for apparell is built vpon his back,
and the whole frame stands vpon pins▪ pricke him no more.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you can do it sir, you can do it, I commend you well: Francis Feeble.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What trade art thou Feeble?

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: A womans tailer sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Shall I pricke him sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You may, but if he had bin a mans tailer hee'd a prickt you: wilt thou make as manie holes in an enemies battaile, as thou hast done in a womans peticoate.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: I will do my good will sir, you can haue no more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well saide good womans tailer, well saide couragious Feeble, thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathfull doue, or most magnanimous mouse, pricke the womans tailer: wel M. Shallow, deepe M. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: I would Wart might haue gone sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I would thou wert a mans tailer, that thou mightst mend him and make him fit to goe, I cannot put him to a priuate souldier, that is the leader of so many thousands, let that suffice most forcible Feeble.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: It shall suffice sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am bound to thee reuerend Feeble, who is next?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Peter Bul-calfe o'th greene.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea mary, lets see Bul-calfe.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Eal.
sp.p: Fore God a likely fellow, come pricke Bul-calfe til hee roare againe.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: O Lord, good my lord captaine.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What, dost thou roare before thou art prickt?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: O Lord sir, I am a diseased man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What disease hast thou?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: A horson cold sir, a cough sir, which I cought with ringing in the Kings affaires vpon his coronation day sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt go to the warres in a gowne, we wil haue away thy cold, and I wil take such order that thy friendes shal ring for thee. Is here all?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Here is two more cald then your number, you must
haue but foure here sir, and so I pray you goe in with mee to dinner.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, I wil go drink with you, but I cannot tary dinner: I am glad to see you, by my troth master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: O sir Iohn, do you remember since we lay all night in the windmil in saint Georges field?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No more of that master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha, twas a merry night, and is lane Night-worke aliue?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: She liues master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: She neuer could away with me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Neuer neuer, she wold alwaies say, she could not abide master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: By the masse I could anger her too●th heart, she was then a bona roba, doth she hold her owne wel?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Old old master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay she must be old, she cannot chuse but be old, certain shees old, & had Robin Night-work by old Night-work, before I came to Clements inne.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p: Thats fiftie fiue yeare ago.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha cousen Scilens that thou hadst seene that that this Knight and I haue seene, ha sir Iohn, said I wel?

sp.speaker: Fal
sp.p: We haue heard the chimes at midnight M. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: That we haue that we haue, that we haue, in faith sir Iohn we haue, our watch-worde was Hemboies, come lets to dinner, come lets to dinner, Iesus the daies that wee haue seene, come, come. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Good maister corporate Bardolfe, stand my friend, & heres foure Harry tenshillings in french crowns for you, in very truth sir,. I had as liue be hangd sir as go, and yet for mine owne part sir I do not care, but rather because I am vnwilling, and for mine owne part haue a desire to stay with my friends, else sir I did not care for mine owne part so much.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Go to, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p:
And good M. corporall captaine, for my old dames sake stand my friend, she has no body to doe any thing about
her when I am gone, and she is old and cannot helpe her selfe, you shall haue forty sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Go to, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: By my troth I care not, a man can die but once, we owe God a death, ile nere beare a base mind, and't bee my destny: so, and't be not, so, no man's too good to serue's prince, and let it go which way it will, he that dies this yeere is quit for the next.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Well said, th'art a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: Faith ile beare no base mind.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come sir, which men shall I haue?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Foure of which you please.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Sir, a word with you, I haue three pound to free Mouldy and Bulcalfe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, well.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come sir Iohn, which foure wil you haue?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do you chuse for me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Mary then, Mouldy, Bulcalfe, Feeble, and Sadow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mouldy and Bulcalfe, for you Mouldy stay at home, til you are past seruice: and for your part Bulcalfe, grow til you come vnto it, I will none of you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
